Other Answers (13) Show: All Answers Oldest to Newest Newest to Oldest Rated Highest to Lowest by It Member since: April 26, 2009 Total points: 377 (Level 2) Add Contact Block i was a chef i went to college but i still started as a waiter like everyone else. and the meaning if tip is T=to , I=improve, P=performance. tips are meant to tell a waiter of waitress that you think they are doing a good job and that they are appreciated. so to tip a waitress or waiter even if you are unhappy then you may send the wrong message that they are doing fine checking on tables every thirty minute or something of that range. i hope i helped. Source(s): chef school, and experience. 2 years ago Report Abuse 0% 0 Votes 2 people rated this as good by smrtblon... Member since: December 30, 2007 Total points: 8,467 (Level 5) Add Contact Block Average to good service gets 10-15% of the PRE-TAX bill. But there's zero tip if: - People who arrive after me get water, order taken and/or food before me - The waitress gives me anything less than a friendly smile and charming attitude - They appear lazy, insincere, would rather talk or hang out with coworkers than work the tables - Simply doing the bare minimum.
However, if something goes wrong but the room is crowded and she's running around trying to keep up, I'll still tip. It's not her fault if the owner is too cheap to hire adequate staff. But NO WAY do I believe waitresses deserve a tip simply for showing up to work. I couldn't care less if they live off tips - I work hard for my money and I don't get tips, so when I go out to dinner I EXPECT excellent service. If I don't get what I expect, then no tip.
Period. 2 years ago Report Abuse 14% 1 Vote 1 person rated this as good by Duck is Quackers is Married! Member since: October 17, 2010 Total points: 38,726 (Level 7) Badge Image: Add Contact Block It's a rare occasion when that's ok. Wait staff usually have to work really hard. I would say that I would be more likely to decrease a tip than to leave no tip. Things that would cause me to do that would be repeatedly getting my order wrong, not offering drink or water refills throughout an entire meal, bringing food that is supposed to be hot to the table cold. If the service is decent, I tip a minimum of 20%. 2 years ago Report Abuse 14% 1 Vote 1 person rated this as good by Lemonade dude Member since: June 17, 2007 Total points: 816 (Level 2) Add Contact Block Being anything where you have to tend to the customers is a very difficult job. I usually tip them almost always I don't tip them if they are trying to work as little as possible and being rude

Answer hidden due to its low rating I waitressed for a year and there were a few occasions when I knew I didn't deserve a tip: -There was something wrong with your food that was NOT the kitchens fault. Waitresses have very little control over what happens in the kitchen. -No re-fills for an unreasonable amount of time. -Extreme rudeness -Dirty table, cups, silverware, ect. * But always remember that waitresses live off of tips, yeah they get a paycheck but they are a joke and normally void because of taxes. 2 years ago Report Abuse 0% 0 Votes
